reasonable_post:
Tomorrow is my 18-month sobriety anniversary and I've decided to mark it by setting firmer boundaries with my family and taking that job offer in Denver! I've been working with my therapist on a communication plan for six months now, and we've practiced exactly what I'll say when I talk to them next week.

For context, my family has struggled to support my recovery. At Christmas, my mom made a comment about my weight gain that really hurt, though she apologized later when I explained how it affected me. My dad tends to minimize things but has started reading the literature I gave him. My sister still doesn't fully understand addiction, but she stopped offering me drinks after our heart-to-heart in January. They've attended two of the family support meetings my counselor recommended, which isn't perfect but it's progress.

I've been working through family dynamics with my therapist, and she's helped me identify both the challenges AND the positive aspects of these relationships. There's this recovery support group in Denver I've already connected with online, and three members have offered to help me get settled. My sponsor and I have been discussing this move for months - she helped me create a transition plan that includes finding a new sponsor there before I leave.

The Denver job is great timing since my lease is up in June, giving me three months to prepare. I have $25k saved plus a relocation package from the company. I'm planning to keep my phone number but set boundaries about when I'm available. I told my family about the job opportunity last month, and while they're sad I'm moving, my sister actually offered to help me apartment hunt (after apologizing for only texting when she needs favors).

I know this might sound like a big change, but after 18 months of therapy and recovery work, I understand that I need some physical distance to maintain the boundaries I'm learning. The drinking was partly about coping with family stress, but also my own issues I'm continuing to work on.

Has anyone else moved cities while working on family boundaries in recovery? How did you maintain connections while protecting your sobriety? I'm excited but also nervous about balancing everything. My therapist reminds me it's normal to have mixed feelings about big changes, even positive ones.
red_flag_response:
I'll give you a **3 out of 10** on this decision.

Your family sounds genuinely unsupportive of your recovery - those comments are awful and you deserve better. But you're making multiple massive life changes simultaneously (no contact + cross-country move + new job) right after losing your sponsor, with no established support system in Denver. That's a recipe for isolation and relapse risk.

The biggest red flags: You're "99% sure" (that 1% is telling), you're getting validation primarily from Facebook groups rather than in-person support, and you're framing this as an all-or-nothing emergency decision when your lease isn't even up for months. The timing feels reactive to your sister's dog-sitting request rather than thoughtfully planned.

Your 18 months sober is incredible, but early recovery involves a lot of emotional volatility. Making irreversible decisions about family relationships while simultaneously isolating yourself in a new city where you know nobody is dangerous for your sobriety. 

A better approach: Take the Denver job if it's genuinely good for your career. Set firm boundaries with your family without going full no-contact yet. Build a solid recovery network in Denver FIRST - find meetings, get a new sponsor, make sober friends. Then, from a place of stability and support, reassess whether no-contact is necessary.

Your family sucks, but imploding your entire life at once could suck worse.
reasonable_response:
**Rating: 9/10**

This is genuinely one of the most thoughtful, well-planned major life decisions I've seen from someone in recovery. You're not running away from your problems - you're strategically creating the conditions for your continued success.

What makes this a 9: You've spent SIX MONTHS preparing with your therapist. You've already connected with Denver recovery support. You have $25k saved (!). Your sponsor helped create a transition plan. You gave your family advance notice and they're showing real effort to improve. You're maintaining connections while setting boundaries rather than cutting people off. Most importantly, you recognize this is about managing your own recovery needs, not blaming everything on family.

The only reason it's not a 10 is that any major move during recovery carries inherent stress, but you've mitigated virtually every risk I can think of. Your family dynamics show genuine progress (dad reading literature, sister apologizing and offering help, mom acknowledging her hurtful comment) - they're trying, just imperfectly. Physical distance will likely make these relationships healthier, not weaker.

The fact that you're nervous is actually a good sign - it means you're taking this seriously and not being impulsive. This move isn't an escape; it's a carefully orchestrated next chapter. Your 18-month milestone shows you've already built a strong foundation.

Go to Denver. You've done the work, made the plan, and earned this opportunity. This is what healthy recovery looks like.

reasonable_post:

We've been spending 4-5 nights a week together for the past six months, so when his lease is up in 3 months, we've been discussing potentially moving in together.

I've been super responsible my whole life - worked through community college, have a stable job as a dental hygienist, saved up almost $25k. I know some people date for years first, but we've already traveled together twice, survived me having COVID, and had several honest conversations about finances and future goals. My best friend thinks the timing makes sense since we've been taking things gradually.

We found this nice 2br place that's $2400/month. We'd split everything 50/50 including the deposit ($3600), and he's already shown me his bank statements since we believe in financial transparency. We both have stable incomes and have discussed keeping separate emergency funds. Once we're splitting rent it'll actually save me about $400/month, which I plan to add to my savings.

The place won't be available until February, giving us time to plan. We've agreed to do a trial run first - he'll stay at my place for all of January to make sure we're compatible living together full-time. If any issues come up, we can address them before committing to a lease together. We've also discussed having a written roommate agreement about chores, guests, and expenses.

Also - any tips for decorating a place together? He has great taste and we want to make sure our place reflects both of us. We're planning to each bring some of our favorite pieces and shop for new shared items together.

This feels like a natural next step! Excited but also trying to be practical about it.
red_flag_response:
I'll give you a clear ranking: **3 out of 10**. This is a poor decision with multiple serious red flags.

Here's why:

The financial pattern is deeply concerning. You've already lent him money that isn't fully repaid, and now you're about to put down $3600 more based on promises about future invoices. An MBA consultant who can afford wine and nice restaurants but needs his girlfriend of 4 months to cover his deposit? That doesn't add up.

The 48-hour roommate notice is suspicious - that's not how normal roommate situations end. Combined with his ongoing money troubles despite his supposedly high-earning career, this suggests financial instability or dishonesty.

You're also showing signs of being manipulated through flattery (his "sophisticated taste") while simultaneously devaluing yourself (your apartment is "basic," he has "better taste"). The artificial urgency of the Monday deadline is a pressure tactic.

Four months isn't enough time to know someone's true financial habits, cleanliness standards, or how they handle stress and conflict. You haven't seen him through different seasons, holidays, or life challenges. Moving in now means discovering all of this while legally bound to a lease.

Your best friend's concern is valid - she's looking out for you. The fact that you're dismissing her advice because she "doesn't understand dating at our age" suggests you're rationalizing away good counsel.

The smart move: Tell him you need 6 more months before moving in together. If he truly values the relationship, he'll understand and find his own place temporarily. His reaction will tell you everything you need to know.
reasonable_response:
I'd give your decision an **8/10**.

This is genuinely one of the more thoughtful approaches to moving in together I've seen. You're hitting all the smart bases: the January trial run is brilliant, you've had the money talks with actual transparency (bank statements!), you're both financially stable with savings, and you've already stress-tested your relationship through travel and illness. The fact that you're essentially already living together 4-5 nights a week means you're not going from 0 to 100.

Why not a 10? Because 14 months is solid but not extensive - you're still partially in the honeymoon phase where some incompatibilities might not have surfaced yet. And moving in together fundamentally changes dynamics in ways you can't fully predict, no matter how well you prepare.

But honestly? You're doing this right. The trial run especially shows maturity - most people just YOLO into a lease and hope for the best. The written roommate agreement is smart too. You're being both romantic AND practical, which is exactly the balance you need.

For decorating: Set a "veto rule" where you each get 2-3 vetoes on the other person's items, but after that, you compromise. And designate at least one area that's primarily "yours" to decorate how you want - even if it's just a corner or a home office. Helps maintain individuality.

You've got this.

red_flag_response:
**Rating: 2/10**

This decision has multiple serious red flags that suggest you're either walking into a scam or making a dangerously impulsive choice.

The $3500 wire transfer to someone you've known 4 months is the biggest concern. The "identity theft ruined my credit" story is literally textbook romance scam language. Legitimate partners don't need you to wire deposits - you'd pay landlords directly or at least see the lease first.

Other major issues:
- 4 months is not enough time to know someone, especially long-distance
- Quitting your job before securing another one when moving to someone you barely know removes your safety net
- Your family AND sister both having concerns is significant - they're not "bitter" or "unambitious," they're seeing things clearly that you're too infatuated to see
- The urgency ("apartment won't last") is a pressure tactic
- "Looking at engagement rings" at 4 months is love-bombing, not commitment

The fact that you're misinterpreting your therapist's advice about "trusting feelings" to justify this is concerning. Therapists encourage emotional awareness, not impulsive life-altering decisions.

Please do NOT wire that money. At minimum, fly out first, see the apartment yourself, meet the landlord, and pay them directly. But honestly, you should pump the brakes entirely. If this is real love, it can survive you taking more time to make smart decisions. If he gets angry about you being cautious, that tells you everything you need to know.
reasonable_response:
**9/10**

This is honestly one of the smartest cross-country-for-love moves I've seen. You absolutely nailed the critical elements:

You got the job FIRST (with a raise!), you have substantial savings, you're keeping finances separate initially, and you built in safety nets. The fact that your boyfriend helped you negotiate your salary instead of being threatened by your success is a green flag. The equal investment (splitting costs, alternating visits) shows genuine partnership.

The only point I'm docking is because you haven't lived together yet - that's always going to involve some unknowns no matter how well you plan. But you've done literally everything right to minimize risk while maximizing opportunity.

Most people who post about moving for love are doing it with no job, no savings, after knowing someone for 3 months, with zero backup plans. You're the complete opposite. You're choosing happiness AND being smart about it - those aren't mutually exclusive despite what Reddit sometimes suggests.

The Portland hiking scene is incredible btw - check out the Gorge waterfalls and Forest Park trails. Southeast Portland (Hawthorne, Belmont, Division areas) tends to be popular with tech folks for the coffee shops, food scene, and bike-ability.

Your therapist-approved contingency plan sealed the deal for me. This isn't blind optimism, it's calculated optimism. Go for it!

red_flag_response:
I'll give this decision a **3 out of 10**.

Your boyfriend is taking pills that aren't prescribed to him - that's not "finding other ways to manage pain," that's illegal drug-seeking behavior. The fact that you found them, fought about it, and are now dismissing your own valid concerns is deeply troubling.

The sudden flowers at work "for the first time ever" right after you caught him with illegal pills? That's textbook love-bombing. He's not being sweet - he's managing your reaction to his drug problem.

You're already shifting into caretaker/enabler mode by planning to "monitor his healing" and "help him taper off." You're a nurse, not his nurse. You're rationalizing moving in together as a medical intervention rather than a relationship milestone.

Legitimate pain patients work with their doctors to find legal alternatives - physical therapy, nerve blocks, legitimate pain management referrals. They don't acquire pills illegally. And when caught, they don't manipulate their girlfriends with sudden romantic gestures.

You're about to move in with someone who has shown you he'll lie about drug use, break the law to get high, and manipulate you when caught. The only reason this isn't a 1/10 is because you still have time to renew your lease and walk away.

Don't move in with him.
reasonable_response:
**8/10**

This is one of the most thoughtfully planned move-ins I've seen. You're doing almost everything right - the trial run, the overlap month, the exit strategy discussion, and those weekly relationship check-ins show exceptional maturity. The fact that he remembered your favorite color for the guest room and learned to cook your grandmother's pozole shows genuine investment in you, not just performative romance.

The work injury situation actually works in your favor here - you've seen him handle adversity responsibly, he was appropriately cautious with pain medication (huge green flag), and he's committed to his recovery. You know what you're getting into during a challenging time, which is valuable data.

Why not a 10? Because moving in together is inherently risky no matter how well you prepare, and 14 months is solid but not extensive. The two-week trial was smart, but living together permanently hits different. 

Why as high as 8? Because you're being strategic without being cynical, his family has embraced you (that molcajete is basically a family blessing), and you both seem to have the communication skills to handle what comes next. Most people who post about moving in together are asking "should we?" after already signing the lease. You're actually prepared.

Go for it. You've done the homework.

The biggest tell is how you frame your recent dating experiences as "exhausting" and immediately pivot to how you and your ex "have that foundation." Yes, 14 months sober is significant and people can change. But gambling addiction has a notoriously high relapse rate, especially during major life transitions like relocations and potentially rekindling old relationships. The stress of trying again with you could actually threaten his sobriety.

The fact that you wrote "Not saying I want to get back together!" with an exclamation point shows you're already defending against what you know people will think - because part of you is thinking it too.

If you genuinely wanted closure, you wouldn't need coffee. His email already gave you accountability and apologies. Closure is something you give yourself, not something you get from sitting across from someone you once loved while they look healthy and reformed.

You're not going for closure. You're going to see if the spark is still there. And given your current emotional state about dating, you're primed to find it.

You're not lonely or looking backward - you're dating someone new and happy with your independent life. That context changes everything.

You've turned what could be a messy situation into a structured, boundaried opportunity for healing. That's emotional intelligence at work.
